tweets.text: Trump‘s critique at G7 that EU companies earn more in the US than vice versa is wrong. The deficit in goods trade is overcompensated by services and primary incomes. The US has a bilateral current account surplus with the EU of 14bn USD in 2017.

Great thread @awstojanovic but perhaps misses major point: The UK has already agreed to a NI/IRL-specific protocol.
It is specific for good reasons: land border, 1998 Agmt.
Those conditions do not apply elsewhere in UK.
They are the grounds for EU's unique flexibility towards NI. https://t.co/zRv4hL1JLi

Together with my 28 fellow EU Member States Ambassadors to the US, we set the record straight on EU-US trade. The facts speak for themselves: the US makes more money doing business with us than anywhere else. @washingtonpost https://t.co/1sHmlMI7He

“Customs union” is a technical term, @bbcnickrobinson. “Customs arrangement” is not. 

A customs union has the same external tariffs on imports from outside the group.

A customs arrangement can be any kind of arrangement involving customs. Could be anything.

@AllieRenison @pmdfoster @StefaanDeRynck @ChathamHouse Converted and then shelved save for occasional updates as UK and EU strike agreements on remaining separation issues.  to @ChathamHouse

Transition hardline - no early harvest (as HMT hopes):

8/ De Rynck on Govt's red lines: 'UK will have less obligations to EU, that’s essence of taking back control. Other consequence is UK will have less benefits. At heart of discussion will no doubt be benefits that are lost as a result of obligations renounced.'
